statement:
For any ${\varepsilon}>0$ there exists $R \geq 4$ with the following property: if $a,b$ are two elements of a group $G$, $B_{a,b}(R) \subset G$ is the collection of all words in $a,b,a^{-1},b^{-1}$ of length at most $R$ so in particular $B_{a,b}(R)$ contains $[a,b]$, and the map ${\ell}: B_{a,b}(R) \to [0,+\infty)$ is a “local semi-length function” which obeys the triangle inequality 

$${\ell({ xy })} \leq {\ell({x})} + {\ell({y})}$$

 whenever $x,y,xy \in B_{a,b}(R)$, with equality when $x=y$, then one has 

$${\ell({ [a,b] })} \leq {\varepsilon}( {\ell({a})} + {\ell({b})} ).$$
